STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 18, 2021
Jason Lheureux
Wedgwood Christian Services
3300 36th St. Grand Rapid
Grand Rapids, MI 49512
RE: License #: CI410201226
Kentwood Campus
3300 36th Street, SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49512-2810
Dear Mr. Lheureux:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
2/8/2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
One of twenty-five files of employee’s hired since the last inspection did not have
verification of a diploma or GED within the file.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or
other country where the person usually resides or has resided in
the previous 5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or other
country law enforcement agency where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
4

Four of twenty-five staff lacked a completed 1326 in the file, as required. One of the
four the staff was hired on 11/23/20, but the 1326 was not processed until 12/1/20,
one of the four lacked a 1326 altogether, and two of the four documented that a
1326 was submitted to DCWL and processed, but the facility did not have the
completed 1326 in their files,
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human services, the equivalent
state or Canadian provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the country where the
person usually resides, that the person has not been determined to be a perpetrator
of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment and every 12 months thereafter.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Eight and twenty-five files of employee’s hired since the last inspection reviewed did
not have a written evaluation completed, as required. In four of the eight files a letter
removing the staff from probation period was found, but no evaluation of the staff’s
performance was completed. In the other four files a probationary written evaluation
was not completed within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
LSR dated 2/12/2019; Corrective Action Plan Approved 2/19/2019
LSR dated 2/18/2020; Corrective Action Plan Approved 3/6/2020
R 400.4161 Seclusion rooms; policies and procedures.
An institution approved to use a seclusion room shall establish
and follow written policies and procedures specifying its use.
The policy shall include, at a minimum, all of the following
provisions:
(g) The room shall be equipped to minimize suicide risk and
risk of physical injury. Break-resistant glass glazing and/or
security screening shall be provided.
During the unannounced onsite inspection, the seclusion room in the Zondervan
home was observed to contain a table, chair, and heavy extension cord. The Chief
Administrator stated that the room is used for Telehealth meetings.
5

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
RFCAN Contractor Responsibilities-Services to be Provided-
2.10.b.1.2. Standardized Assessment Tools
The Contractor shall utilize the following assessment tools
to assess the child’s needs and strengths while in the
residential program:
2) Ansell Casey Life Skills or Daniel Memorial Assessment
(For children 14 years of age and older)
The Contractor may utilize additional standardized and
reliable assessment tools to assess overall progress in
functioning. Additional program specific assessment tools
are identified within each program type in Attachment A.
The Contractor shall administer the assessment tools
within 30 calendar days of admission, and quarterly
thereafter until planned discharge. An unplanned discharge
is defined as an immediate (one calendar day or less) move
from the Contractor’s program as directed by the court or
caseworker. Children who are Absent Without Legal
Permission (AWOLP) are also considered an unplanned
discharge.
Two of three open residential youth files reviewed did not have the required
assessments completed according to the prescribed timeframes. One file contained
an assessment completed after the youth had been placed at the facility over 30
days and the other has not had a new assessment in since 8/5/2020. The third file
reviewed was of a youth under the age of 14, thus the assessment is not required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
The human resources department expressed confusion about the 1326 clearance
process as they were continuing to request central registry and criminal history
clearances independently and not waiting for the DCWL completed 1326 before hiring
new employees, as is required. Additionally, the HR department was under the
6

impression that they could hire any employee with a pending out of state clearance,
even if they had not received the DCWL completed 1326, citing an email they
believed gave this direction. The email they cited did state that waiting for an out of
state clearance should not prevent hiring; however, the email continued on to state
that, even in the case of a pending out of state clearance, the DCWL completed 1326
must be obtained prior to hire.
V. CONSULTATION
No consultation was required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. These CAPs have been monitored quarterly
for compliance.
During the unannounced inspection the majority of the youth were at school;
however, at least two youth were observed in each home to be either working on
schoolwork or completing chores. No concerns were raised by interviews conducted
with neither the youth nor staff interviewed. Structurally, there were some minor
repairs being completed while I was on-site to address issues identified during the
environmental inspection, which resulted in that inspector issuing an “A” rating.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
February 18, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:

February 18, 2021
